reviewText:
A minefield you can traverse by running round the back of it, an on-rails boat ride and a train station with two rooms.  Push some pillars around, run to a generator and it's goodnight, god bless.

Granted, I didn't explore every inch of the map but then I'm guessing the developer didn't either because I fell through it twice.

Save yourself a playthrough and watch mine.

reviewText:
This ultra low budget horror adventure game starts out with you having crashed your truck in the forest, upon where you immediately find a note (personally addressed to you!) from some dark forest lord named The Keeper, telling you to leave or else. However, he's kind enough to let you know in precise detail that the generator beyond the river is where he harnesses his power, but you'll never stop him anyway because you don't have the gas can, key and cable to get the generator running.

No kidding, that's what he says in his note.

I spent about 30 minutes ambling around a hideously ugly forest that mostly consists of dirt and a sparse few PS1-era trees, picking up giant battery packages to keep my flashlight running and avoiding land mines seemingly drawn in MS Paint before I decided I had enough of this game. If you tried Nyctophobia for free you'd probably be angry at the time wasted in downloading and playing it, never mind spending a fiver for this dubious privilege.

It should also be noted that this evil spirit of the forest and darkness wrote his sinister warning message on spiral bound notebook paper. Perhaps The Keeper" is short for "The Trapper Keeper.""

reviewText:
AN UTTER FAILURE THAT CAN ONLY BE EXPLAINED AS DESIGNER MALEFICENCE
Category        Score        Comment                Fun/Horror        1/4        It is difficult to review a game that has as many problems as this. There is no fun to be had and the few jump scares present in the game do not justify the time spent                Controls
/Gameplay        1/4        There is almost no attempt to provide an immersive horror experience, and the controls/gameplay continually detract from enjoying what limited gameplay is present.                Graphics        1/4        2D sprites and circa 2000 graphics in a 3D game written in 2015 represent laziness, poor design decisions, or a simple lack of competence that treads dangerously close to designer maleficence                Sound        1/4        When the sound actually works, it is ham-fisted. In terms of music, I am a big fan of Kevin MacLeod, but his compositions are wasted here (and as another reviewer pointed out, at least credit the guy properly!)                 Replayability        1/4        I couldnâ€™t even finish the game the first time and have no desire to play this game ever again.
Overall = 25% - The lowest score I can give to a game that actually loads and runs at least once. I donâ€™t even feel like giving a snarky comment here. Just donâ€™t give this game any of your time.

I gave up at the land mines. I tried to look for scares but instead I either died from being scared of the dark or I stepped on a landmine. voteText: 9 of 9 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The world of indie gaming will never cease to amaze me. Just like the world of triple A title, it is crowded with cheap knock-off and copycats. Who thought that making a Slender clone without Slender would be a good idea?

In Nyctophobia the real threat is not an entity but your own fear of the dark. In order to survive you must pick up batteries floating around the map since your flashlight can't last more than 1 minute. If you don't do that darkness will overwhelm you and you will be greeted with a game over screen. That's some lazy game design, isn't it? Not to mention the minefield that stands between you and the gas can that you must pick up to progress. It just feels out of place.

At the end of the game a silly looking shadow chases you and the only thing you have to do to survive this encounter is to make your way to the safety zone before it gets you.

The only positive thing about the game is its ambiant sound effects which gave me the chills at some moments but that's all.

To summarize, Nyctophobia is absolutely not worth a buy. Wait for someone to gift it to you instead. It takes no more than 20 minutes to beat the game on the first playthrough.

Here's the proof :
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ze-uP9hkbSE

Rating :
1.5
voteText: 9 of 10 people (90%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I'm not a huge fan of walking simulators, so let's get that out of the way first. Cause that's basically what this game is: a timed walking simulator.

The game requires you to find randomized checkpoints in the form of batteries to stay alive. Your only clues on where to go are based on question marks on the map that you have to manually go find to look at. If you go off exploring too much, you can easily die due to there not being any battery packs in that area.

I highly recommend using the guide.

Sounds: In terms of sound, the game is pretty boring. There were a couple of sounds that felt right, but overall the sounds felt a bit forced. There is no depth of sound either. In Own the Night mode, it doesn't matter if a zombie is 1 foot from you, or 20 feet from you, the sound level is the same. No volume scaling based on distance at all.

Issues with Clipping: Clipping occurs often during this game, so when you try to enter certain areas, you may not be able to without wiggling your way in, which makes absolutely no sense. Further, as you're walking along, random things can catch you, and you might slow down for no apparent reason.

Graphics: Visually the graphics are low quality, but I don't think that was the main goal of the designers.

Controls: If you use two monitors, I would highly recommend disabling the second monitor during play, because the game gets confused when your mouse leaves the window/fullscreen area of its existence. I was often walking in strange directions or having the screen flip and move around due to mouse position on the other monitor. It was rather frustrating.

Interface: While the game says its supports inverted mouse control on the y-axis, whenever I tried to select yes" the game just laughed at me and did nothing. I could also select no
date: and the same thing happened. Nothing. When you want to access the menu
recommended: you press escape.... often I'd have to press it twice to bring it up
hoursPlayed: but not always. Something weird was going on there.\n\nStory: Fairly weak
voteText: as the premise itself is obviously flawed. You have a deep terrifying fear of the night
helpfulPercent: and yet for some reason you've decided to go out for a drive in the middle of no where
votesHelpful: at night. Whatever. While the game attempts to piece together some sort of semblence of a story
votesTotal: it just seems a bit forced as if they came up with a game mechanic and designed something around it.\n\nOverall: Fairly boring

reviewText:
NOTE: This is more of a bug log as well as an overview of things that I believe should be added/improved/fixed.

Some issues I noticed:
- Frontend UI needs a lot of work, it feels really rough right now. I'd suggest splitting the Controls screen off into its own page with its own button.
- In the How to Play" page
date:
the way the text and graphics are laid out make it extremely difficult to be able to comprehend what I'm supposed to do. I mocked up a quick wireframe of how I'd recommend you do it: https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/38430663/DesignShit/Nyctophobia-TutorialUIWireframe.png Note: The images of the battery meter should be small enough so they're no taller than the height of the line of text they're inserted into.
- Typo in "How to Play" page: "acess" should be spelled "access".
- There's virtually zero payoff for dying. A black screen saying "you died" without the player ever even seeing the monster (unless I guess the monster is darkness itself?) isn't exactly horrifying. Modern horror typically demands a build of tension with some sort of payoff or release. Extra Credits has an excellent video on this: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OyiAR2BXtKU
- When the player spawns
recommended: I don't think you should have the player character directly talk about the battery indicator at the top of the screen. Instead
hoursPlayed: I think you should have them say something like
voteText: "My flashlight's batteries are limited
helpfulPercent: so I should do my best to make sure that they don't run out."\n- I highly recommend that you don't use icons in the pause menu
votesHelpful: I'd use normal buttons with text instead. Or
votesTotal: what you could do is when the mouse hovers over a button
votesFunny: have text appear under the button that says what it does.\n- There should be some sort of confirmation message for restarting the game when I press the button to do so
commentsCount:
as well as for when I press the button that takes me back to the main menu.
- Kevin MacLeod's music isn't being credited correctly. Here's how he requests it be done: http://incompetech.com/music/royalty-free/faq.html It is very important that this is fixed as soon as possible.
- The footstep sounds should be quieter.

Overall
column16: I like the atmosphere you've created - it has a very nice aesthetic
column17: despite its jarring lack of polish
column18: but there remains a lot of work to be done overall. Giving this a thumbs down for the time being
column19: at least until most of these are addressed in some form."

reviewText:
This is the work of a dev clearly still learning the ropes of game making. The writing is very blunt and naive, the art usable, and the gameplay workable, though not particularly exciting. Smaller glitches abound.

Only get this game if you feel like giving a newbie a chance and to collect feedback to let them know how to improve on this.

To the devs: The button to close notes is off-screen on smaller game resolutions, making it seem as if they are unclosable.

reviewText: There are a lot of good horror games out there, and they're free. And what about Nyctophobia? It's just someone slapping some random assets together, taking a few pre-written scripts, packing them together and call it a game. Even if it's free, it's still not worth. Story is generic and predictable, narrative is bad, GUI is poorly designed, level design just sucks bad and gameplay is very boring. The design of the game also has many flaws which hamper the experience, for example, you die when the flashlight is out of battery, and who'd throw all the batteries in a dark, abandoned woods anyway?\n\nGet something else. This game is not even worth $0.99.

reviewText: I know the developer so take that as you will.  The game has been fun to play and there are several good moments in the game. I took the game to be a somewhat goofy horror game. There are quite a few fun elements to the game; collecting batteries, finding notes, getting chased. There are also a few issues with the game. Overall though, the game is fun to play and suffers from a few bugs that the developer has been fixing. I have 15 minutes on record on steam but probably a few hours on record in total. I think if you rush through the game you could finish it in 20 minutes but otherwise the game should take 45ish minutues.

reviewText: The graphics aren't like amazing or anything but it's definitley fun. Like it's got a spooky feel to it. I really felt like I was freaking out on that train station level. The music is good and I like the leave crunching sounds. I played it with my friend and she thought it was cool too but it was kinda hard which was annoying. There's probably scarier games but this was at least fun and cool to explore.

reviewText: Personally I found the game to be quite enjoyable. It's an indie game, but I thought the graphics were nice looking in game. It scared me a few times and I thought the atmosphere was really immersive. It's a good game for the price. And the achieveements are a challenge which is something I appreciate. I say give it a go.
